skill.name: agentic-jujutsu
skill.description: Quantum-resistant, self-learning version control for AI agents with ReasoningBank intelligence and multi-agent coordination
skill.summary: Quantum-resistant, self-learning version control for AI agents with ReasoningBank intelligence and m...
skill.author: ruvnet

security_audit.summary: This is a documentation-only skill (SKILL.md) describing a version control system. No executable code is present in the skill directory. The described functionality involves version control operations, agent coordination, and cryptography - all legitimate use cases. The actual npm package would require separate audit.

content.user_title: Enable self-learning version control for AI agents
content.value_statement: Managing multiple AI agents working on the same codebase creates conflicts and coordination overhead. Agentic Jujutsu provides lock-free version control with self-learning capabilities that improve over time and resolve conflicts automatically.
actual_capabilities: Enable multiple AI agents to commit simultaneously without locks (23x faster than Git)
Track and learn from successful workflows using ReasoningBank intelligence
Automatically resolve code conflicts with 87% success rate
Generate quantum-resistant SHA3-512 fingerprints for commit integrity
Discover and apply patterns from successful operation sequences
Query past trajectories to get AI-powered suggestions for new tasks
limitations: Requires the agentic-jujutsu npm package installation
Learning effectiveness depends on recording sufficient trajectory data
Quantum-resistant features are for future-proofing, not current threat mitigation
Pattern recognition requires 3-5 successful trajectories before recommendations improve

use_cases.title: Coordinate AI Agents
use_cases.description: Enable multiple AI agents to work on the same codebase simultaneously without merge conflicts or blocking.

use_cases.title: Learn Deployment Patterns
use_cases.description: Track deployment workflows and let the system learn successful patterns for smarter future recommendations.

use_cases.title: Build Self-Improving Agents
use_cases.description: Create agents that learn from experience and improve their success rate over time through trajectory tracking.

prompt_templates.title: Track First Workflow
prompt_templates.prompt: Use agentic-jujutsu to start a new trajectory for [describe task]. Track all operations. When complete, record the outcome with a success score and brief critique.

prompt_templates.title: Get Smart Suggestion
prompt_templates.prompt: Query agentic-jujutsu for suggestions on [task description]. Report the confidence level, reasoning, and recommended operations. Execute if confidence exceeds 70%.

prompt_templates.title: Coordinate Multiple Agents
prompt_templates.prompt: Spin up 3 agentic-jujutsu instances and have each agent start a trajectory for different parts of [feature]. Let them work concurrently and record each outcome.

prompt_templates.title: Review Learned Patterns
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me all discovered patterns from agentic-jujutsu. Include success rates, operation sequences, and confidence scores. Identify the top 3 most reliable patterns.

output_examples.input: Use agentic-jujutsu to help me deploy to production. Start a trajectory and get suggestions.
output: AI Confidence: 78.2% based on 12 past deployments
Past patterns show 89% success rate with this approach

best_practices: Use meaningful, specific task descriptions in startTrajectory to improve pattern recognition quality
Record honest success scores (including partial successes) to build accurate learning data
Finalize trajectories immediately after task completion while details are fresh
anti_patterns: Using vague task descriptions like 'fix stuff' which creates unlearnable patterns
Always reporting 1.0 success scores prevents the system from learning what actually works
Skipping trajectory finalization after failures loses valuable learning opportunities

faq.question: Which Claude tools support this skill?
faq.answer: Agentic Jujutsu works with Claude, Claude Code, and Codex. It requires the npm package installed in your project.

faq.question: How many agents can work simultaneously?
faq.answer: The lock-free architecture supports unlimited concurrent agents. The documentation claims 350 concurrent operations per second.

faq.question: How does it integrate with existing Git repos?
faq.answer: The package wraps Git operations. You can use it alongside existing Git workflows. It tracks operations in AgentDB separately.

faq.question: Is my data safe with the quantum-resistant features?
faq.answer: SHA3-512 fingerprints verify integrity. The HQC-128 encryption uses established algorithms. Data remains on your systems.

faq.question: Why are my suggestions low confidence?
faq.answer: The system needs 5-10 trajectories before making reliable predictions. Record varied successful and failed workflows to improve accuracy.

faq.question: How is this different from regular Git?
faq.answer: Git requires sequential commits with locking. Agentic Jujutsu enables parallel commits without blocking and learns from your workflows.
